342
6.9 Injection molding
Batching
PE
Batching, Forces
Batching
Plasticizing
- Feed distance F.
After injection and application of the packing pressure, 
new molding compound must be prepared for the next 
shot and made available in the appropriate amount.
For the shot batching, the extruder is reset and gran­
ulate filled in. The rotation of the reciprocating screw 
generates a feed flow. The material is warmed up, 
compacted, sheared and homogenized in the heated 
barrel around the reciprocating screw. The plasticized 
compound is driven to the injection nozzle. The required 
shot volume must comprise the molded part volume 
and the sprue volume and make up for the difference in 
density between the molten material and the solidified 
part (e.g. factor 1.25).
During the holding phase, a packing cushion (holding 
cushion) is required to compensate for shrinkage and 
prevent sink marks on the molded part.
V,
injection volume in cm3
injection mass in g
Vmp molded part volume in cm3
mb

Forces
n
projected area
Pt 
Fb 
Fc
•P
The injection pressure drives the compound into the tool. The pressure force 
is applied in the cavity and sprue perpendicular to the respective projected 
area (parting surface) and produces the buoyant force Fb. A clamping force 
Fc that is higher than the buoyant force must apply to prevent leakage of 
the compound. This force is applied mechanically, hydraulically or electro- 
mechanically.

projected area of a cavity in cm2

safety factor

6.10 Joining (Welding)
343
Fusion welding, Welding processes (Overview)
Fusion welding is the permanent joining of material by means of locally limited fusion with the application of
• heat and/or
• metal fillers, such as electrodes, welding wire, for the filling of weld joints
• auxiliary materials, such as shielding gas in order to improve the welding conditions and the weld properties.
Welding processes (selection)
Illustration
Description
Process, application
Gas welding
(page 347)
welding rod 
V
welding 
r torch
gas flame
Heat source
Gas flame of oxygen and acetylene
Preferred flame adjustment: neutral flame with an equal 
portion of oxygen and acetylene
Metal fillers
Bare welding rods (page 347)
Manual welding; fusion 
welding of unalloyed and 
low-alloy steel tubes, repair 
welding on cast iron
Manual arc welding
(page 348)
coated rod 
electrode ’ ,
//?
K arc

AC or DC arc between the consumable electrode and the 
base metal
Temperatures in the fusion area: up to 4000°C (7232°F)

Manual welding; fusion 
welding of alloyed and 
unalloyed steels, fixed- 
position welding
Gas-shielded welding
Gas-shielded metal welding (MIG-, MAG-welding)
(page 346)
wire 
/f
electrode \
shielding 
|
gas \ 
I
arc
Heat source
DC or AC arc between the consumable electrode and the 
workpiece
Metal fillers
Wire electrodes (page 346), tubular cored electrodes
Auxiliary material
Shielding gases are selected in accordance with the base 
metals to be welded and determine the welding method: 
Use of inert gases, such as argon or helium -*  metal 
inert gas (MIG) welding, no chemical reaction of the gas 
with the base metals
Use of active shielding gases such as gases with a CO2 
or O2 portion -» metal active gas (MAG) welding, gases 
have an oxidizing effect on the base metals
Manual or automated 
welding, with welding 
robots for instance; high 
welding quality, high 
deposition efficiency
MIG-welding:
Aluminum and aluminum 
alloys, copper and copper 
alloys, nickel and nickel 
alloys
MAG-welding:
Unalloyed and alloyed 
steels, also stainless Cr-Ni 
steels
Tungsten inert gas welding (TIG-welding)
welding 
rod
tungsten 
electrode 
\
Heat source
DC or AC arc between a non-consumable tungsten 
electrode and the base metal
Metal fillers
Welding rods are applied manually under normal
conditions
Auxiliary material
Inert shielding gases, such as argon or helium -*  no 
chemical reaction of the gas with the base metals
Welding process for high- 
quality joints, particularly 
in combination with thin 
sheet metals; suitable for 
almost all materials, such 
as alloyed and unalloyed 
steels, also stainless Cr-Ni 
steels, non-ferrous metals, 
titanium, tantalum and 
zirconium
Plasma arc welding (PAW)
arc (plasma)
shielding 
gas
Heat source -*  see TIG-welding, bundled arc (plasma) 
with high power
Metal fillers -» see TIG-welding
Auxiliary material
Two kinds of gas are needed for plasma welding:
- plasma gas: mainly argon
- shielding gas: argon with material-dependent compo­
nents such as hydrogen, helium etc.
Welding process for high- 
quality joints with a thick­
ness between 0.01 and 
10 mm, build-up welding, 
e. g. on valve seats; metals 
as with TIG-welding

6.10 Joining (Welding)
Gas-shielded welding
The quality of gas-shielded welds and the welding conditions are influenced by the selection of the wire electrode, 
the shielding gas and the arc adjustment. 
_____________________________________
Gas-shielded welding with 
consumable wire electrode
Base metal
—
Decisive for the welding 
method
steel 
-* * MAG-welding
aluminium -> MIG-welding
The strength and toughness of the weld metal are influenced by the electrode material and shielding gas. The 
designation of the weld metal therefore gives information about the strength, toughness, shielding gas and electrode 
material. Classification in two groups:
• Weld metal with a guaranteed yield strength Re and a notch impact energy of 47 J (ISO 14341-A)
• Weld metal with a guaranteed tensile strength Rm and a notch impact energy of 27 J (ISO 14341 -B)
Designation example (weld metal with guaranteed yield strength and notch impact energy of 47 J):

• pore formation

Properties, application
Low active portion (CO2 and O2), low slag and spatter formation, suitable 
for all arc types, sensitive to rust, cinder and contaminated sheets, 
preferred for bare, thin sheets.
Increased active part (CO2 and O2), higher slug and spatter formation, 
insensitive to rust, cinder and contaminated sheet surfaces, suitable for 
all arc types, higher sheet thicknesses
M22: lower spatter, with pulsed arcs, CO2-portion < 20%

High active portion (CO2 and O2), high slag and spatter formation, 
insensitive to rust, cinder and contamination, unsuitable for pulsed arcs, 
for higher sheet thicknesses with rust and scales.

6.10 Joining (Welding)
PE
Arc welding
Coated rod electrodes for unalloyed steels and fine grain steels 
cf. DIN EN ISO 2560 (2010-03)
The electrode has a decisive influence on the mechanical properties of the welding joint and the welding behavior.
------------------------------------------------ a- rod electrode -----------------------------;--------------------------------
The core wire of the electrode 
\ \\ 
The coating has an influence on
has an influence on 
VA 
• strength and toughness
• the chemical composition of 
\ \A--------------------------- • the ignition and welding behavior
the weld metal 
----------------- • the look of the weld and the penetration
• the strength and toughness 
Hk'- _ 
behavior
• hot and cold cracking
Strength and toughness of the weld metal are the important parameters for the quality of the welding joint. The 
designation of the coated electrodes is based on these criteria and divided into two groups:
• Rod electrodes for weld metal with a guaranteed yield strength and a notch impact energy of 47 J (ISO 2560-A)
• Rod electrodes for weld metal with a guaranteed tensile strength and a notch impact energy of 27 J (ISO 2560-B)
Designation example: electrode for weld metal with a guaranteed yield strength and a notch impact energy of 47 J 
(legally binding specifications as per ISO 2560):

Gas cylinders - Identification
*
Hazardous substance labels
cf. DIN EN ISO 7225 (2008-02)
A hazardous substance label must be applied to individual gas cylinders to identify their contents and any possible 
hazards from these contents. Up to three hazard labels warn of the main hazards.

Color coding
cf. DIN EN 1089-3(2004-06)
Color coding of the cylinder shoulder is used as additional information about the properties of the gases. 
It is readily recognized when the hazardous substance label is illegible from a distance.
This color coding does not apply to liquid gases.

Soldered joint under shearing load
Load transfer
• The load on the soldered joint should be in shear (trans- 
verse forces) if at all possible. In particular, solder seams 
should not be loaded with tensile or peeling stress.
• Soldering gap depths Zd > 5 • s do not fill with solder reli- 
ably. Therefore load capacity cannot be increased by a
Load on solder joint reduced by folded seam 
larger gap depth.

11 Code numbers for type of treatment
1 Cleaning of dirt, scale, rust 
6 Mechanical roughing by grinding or brushing
2 Removing grease with organic solvent 
7 Mechanical roughing by shot blasting
or aqueous cleaning agent 
8 Etching 30 min, at 60°C in 27.5% sulfuric acid solution
3 Rinsing with clear water 
9 Etching 1 min, at 20°C in 20% nitric acid solution
4 Drying in hot air up to 65°C 
10 Etching 3 min, at 20°C in 15% hydrofluoric acid solution
5 Removing grease with simultaneous etching
21 Load severity for bonded joints
Low: 
Tensile shear strength up to 5 N/mm2; dry environment; for precision mechanics, electrical equipment
Medium: Tensile shear strength up to 10 N/mm2; humid air; contact with oil; for machine and vehicule manufacturing 
High: Tensile shear strength up to 10 N/mm2; direct contact with liquids; for aircraft, ship, and container 
manufacturing

358
6.10 Joining (Adhesive bonding)
Design of adhesive bonded joints, Test methods
Design examples
Bonded joints should be loaded in compression or shearing if possible. 
Tensile, peeling or bending loads should be avoided.
Butt joint/overlap joint
good, since the bonding surfaces 
only have a shear load
not as good, 
since peeling forces act due to 
off-center application of force
good, since the bonding surfaces 
only have a shear and 
compression load
since peeling forces act due to 
bending load
Tube joint
good, since sufficiently large 
bonding surfaces can withstand 
shear load
bonding surfaces cannot 
withstand tensile and shear load
Test methods
Test method 
standard
Contents
Bending peel test 
DIN 54461
Tests resistance of bonded joints against peeling forces
Tensile shear test 
DIN EN 1465
Tests tensile shear strength of high-strength bonded lap joints
Fatigue test
DIN EN ISO 9664
Tests fatigue properties of structural adhesives under tensile-shear loads
Tensile test 
DIN EN 15870
Tests tensile strength of bonded butt joints perpendicular to bonded surface
Roller peel test
DIN EN 1464
Tests resistance to peeling forces
Compression shear test
DINEN 15337
Tests shear strength, primarily of anaerobic1’ adhesives
1’ Sets with exclusion of air
PE
Adhesive behavior as a function of temperature and size of bonding surface

overlap bonded joints
Effect of adhesive joint surface 
area on breaking load

6.11 Workplace and environmental protection
363
PE

364
6.11 Workplace and environmental protection
PE

6.11 Workplace and environmental protection
365
Identification of pipe lines
*
cf. DIN 2403 
(2007-05)
Area of application and requirements
Requirements concerning identification marking
• Identification marking must be clearly visible and 
long-lasting.
• Identification can be established by painting, lettering 
(e.g. via self-adhesive foil strips) or signs.
• Particularly operation-critical and hazardous places 
should be marked (e.g. beginning and end of branch 
pipes, wall penetrations, fittings).
Area of application: A precise identification marking of pipe lines, indicating the substance being conveyed, is neces­
sary for reasons of safety, fire fighting and proper maintenance and repairs. The identification marking is intended to 
indicate possible hazards and help to prevent accidents and damage to health.
• Marking must be repeated at least every 10 m of pipe 
length.
• Indication of the group and supplemental color (see 
table below).
• Indication of the flow direction by means of an arrow.
• Indication of the conveyed substance by specifying the 
name (e.g. water) or the chemical formula (e. g. H2O).
• With hazardous materials, additional indication of 
hazard signs (page 363) or warning signs (page 360) 
if general hazards are implied.

Identification of special pipe lines
Fire extinguishing lines must be fitted with a red/white/red color marking. The white field contains the graphical sym­
bol of the safety sign „Fire fighting equipment and materials" (cf. page 361) in the color of the extinguishing agent. 
Potable water lines must be fitted with a green/white/green color marking. Non-potable water lines have a green/ 
blue/green marking. The code letters and their colors are listed in the table below.
Examples of identification marking

Color

366
6.11 Workplace and environmental protection
Sonic terms
Term
Sound
Frequency
Sound level
Noise
Decibel (dB)
dB (A)
PE
Sound and Noise
*
Explanation
Sound comes from mechanical vibrations. It propagates in gaseous, liquid and solid bodies.
Number of oscillations per second. Unit: 1 Hertz = 1 Hz = 1/s. Pitch increases with frequency. 
Frequency range of human hearing: 16 Hz-20.000 Hz.
Measure of the sound strength (sound energy).
Undesirable, annoying or painful sound waves; damage depends on strength, duration, frequency 
and regularity of exposure. For a noise level of 85 dB (A) and higher there is danger of permanent 
hearing loss.
Standardized unit for sound level.
Since the human ear perceives tones of different heights (frequencies) to have different strengths 
when they are actually at the same sound levels, noise must be appropriately dampened with filters 
for certain frequencies. Frequency weighting curve with Filter A compensates for this and indicates 
the subjective auditory impression. A difference of 3 dB (A) corresponds approximately to a 
doubling (or halving) of the sound intensity (energy parameter). A difference of 10 dB (A) corres­
ponds to a doubling (or halving) of the subjectively perceived loudness (psychological parameter).
Sound level
Type of sound
Threshold of 
auditory sensitivity 
Breathing at distance 
of 30 cm
Soft rustling of leaves
Whispering
Tearing paper 
Quiet conversation
dB (A)
10

cf. Accident Prevention Regulations on "Noise" BGV B311 (1997-01)
Accident prevention regulations 
____________ for noise producing operations____________
• Requirem. to post signage for noise ranges 90 dB (A) and above.
• Above 85 dB (A) sound protection devices must be avail­
able, and they must be used above 90 dB (A).
• If the risk of accidents increases due to noise, appropriate 
measures must be taken.
• Regular preventative medical checkups are compulsory.
• New operational equipment must conform to the most 
advanced level of noise reduction.
§ 15 Workplace regulation

368
7.1 Control engineering, Basic terminology
Basic terminology of open loop and closed loop control systems
Basic terminology
cf. DIN 19226-1 to -5 (1994-02), withdrawn
Open loop control
For open loop control the output variable, such as the tem­
perature in a hardening furnace, is influenced by the input 
variable, such as the current in the heating coil. The out­
put variable does not have an effect on the input variable. 
Open loop control has an open action flow.
Closed loop control
For closed loop control the controlled variable, such as the 
actual temp, in an annealing furnace, is continuously mon­
itored and compared to the target temp, (reference vari­
able) and, if there are deviations, adjusted to the reference 
input variable. Closed loop control has a closed action flow.
Example: Annealing furnace

disturbance

7.1 Control engineering, Basic terminology
Analog controllers
Analog (continuous) controllers
cf. DIN 19225 (1981-12) and DIN 19226-2 (1994-02), both withdrawn
In analog controllers the manipulated variable y may assume any desired value within the control range.
Controller design
Level control example, description
Transition function
Symbol1’
1’ Symbol as per DIN 19227-2
3) Signal curve at controlled system input
Block representation2’
P-controllers
Proportional 
controllers
Output variable is 
proportional to 
input variable.
P-controllers 
have steady-state 
errors.
x controlled variable ------ step function3’
y manipulated variable------ step response4’
e error
I-controllers
Integral con­
trollers
I-controllers are 
slower than 
P-controllers, but 
they eliminate all 
errors.
Pl-controllers
Proportional 
integral con­
trollers
In Pl-controllers a 
P-controller and a 
I-controller are 
connected in par­
allel.
D-controllers
Derivative con­
trollers
D-controller systems only occur with P- or PI- 
controller systems, since pure D-controller 
behavior with constant error does not provide 
any manipulated variable and therefore no 
closed loop control.
t---- ►
PD-controllers
Proportional 
derivative con­
trollers
PID-controllers
Proportional 
integral 
derivative con­
trollers
PD-controllers are created when a P controller 
and a D element are connected in parallel.
The D part changes the output variable at a rate 
proportional to the rate of change of the input 
variable. The P part changes the output variable 
so that it is proportional to the input variable 
itself.
PD-controllers act quickly.
PID-controllers are created by connecting P, I 
and D-controllers in parallel.
Initially the D part reacts with a large change 
to the control signal, afterwards this change is 
reduced to approximately the magnitude of the 
P element, and finally the effect of the I element 
causes the response to rise linearly.
2> Block representation as per DIN 19226-2
4> Signal curve at controlled system output
A

7.1 Control engineering, Basic terminology
Representation in information processing
A structogram or Nassi-Shneiderman diagram (NSD) is a type of diagram that allows the graphical design 
representation of structured programming. It was developed in 1972/73 by Isaac Nassi and Ben Shneiderman and is 
incorporated as a standard in DIN 66261. The method divides a complex problem into elementary basic structures 
such as sequences and controlling structures (selection or loop blocks).
Structogram 
cf. DIN 66261 (1985-11)

7.2 Electrical circuits
Circuit diagrams
cf. DIN EN 61082 (2007-03)
Connector markings on relays
Current sections and distribution of electric circuits
Control circuit
Main circuit
3
4
C1
C1
S1F-
82
£1
MiPpK M3
Designing circuit diagrams
52 I—
C1
Representation as contact set
Representation as table
Sec­
tion
Every electrical device is shown with a 
vertical current section regardless of the 
actual spatial arrangement of the ele­
ments.
Current sections are numbered sequen­
tially from left to right.
The control circuit contains devices for 
signal input and signal processing.
The main circuit contains the necessary 
final control elements for the working 
elements.
The spatially shared devices, e. g. relay 
coil and relay contact, are not repre­
sented.
Designation of devices
• Contacts and the associated relay coils 
are marked with the same code numeral. 
Example: Current sections 1, 2 and 3
• 2 NO contacts belong to relay coil C1, 
both marked as C1. They are used to 
latch the relay coil.
• All contacts of a relay are entered as a 
complete contact set or as a table under 
the current path of the relay. Both rep­
resentations indicate the current section 
on which a contact is located.
2^_
3—J.

against direct contact

for indirect contact

7.3 GRAFCET
Function charts for sequential controls (GRAFCET) din en 6084s (2002-121
The function chart in accordance with GRAFCET is a graphical design language for sequential control. However, it 
does not make any statement about the type of devices used, the direction of lines and the installation of electrical 
equipment. Only the general representation via symbols is obligatory; dimensions and other details are left to the 
user.
Important basic terms
GRAFCET
Transition
Variable
French: GRAphe Fonctionel de Commande
Etape Transition (say: grafset)
English: specification language for function 
charts of sequential controls
condition for the transition to the next step 
value that may change
George Boole 
Boolean 
variables
Initial step 
Macro step
British mathematician
TRUE, FALSE
TRUE = logical value 1
FALSE = logical value 0 
first step 
condensed representation of a step 
chain
Basic structure of a GRAFCET
Sequential structure
The basic structure of GRAFCETs consists of:
steps, e. g.
2
actions, e. g.
1A1
interactive 
connections, e. g. I
transitions, e. g. — 1B2
Steps and transitions are transition conditions that 
alternate permanently. In linear sequences, only one 
step is active at a time and can trigger any number of 
actions. In alternative or parallel branchings, several 
steps can be active simultaneously.
Example of a GRAFCET (sequence chart)
Technology schemes and circuit 
diagrams are not part of a GRAFCET, 
but they help considerably to make 
the task more transparent.
Example: belt conveyor
After activation of push button S1, 
cylinder 1A1 pushes the workpiece 
onto a pallet and retracts. Cylinder 
2A1 pushes the workpiece sub­
sequently onto a belt conveyor and 
retracts.
Pneumatic diagram with 
bistable components
RAT11B1 1B2 
[2A112B1 2B2
-------- i i 
-------- i i
Different representation methods of steps in the interactive part
Explicit and abbreviated step description
Example:
A

7.3 GRAFCET
383
Function charts for sequential controls (GRAFCET) 60843^2002-w
Transitions
Example
Explanation
Steps
□
Initial step
The initial step marks the starting position of a controller. It is the first active step after 
starting the program.
General step
2
Step with the step number 2. A step is represented with a square. The step number is 
marked on top in the middle of the text field. In linear sequences, only one step is active 
at a time. In parallel sequence charts, several steps may be active simultaneously.
! 4s/X2
? r 
i
z । 1A1 ext. cyl. |
L^rJ - 
J
+
i- 3 ~i
i____ I
Step variable
The step variable X is composed of the Boolean variable X and the step name (2).
The step variable can have
- either the value 0 = FALSE (step is not active)
- or the value 1 = TRUE (step is active).
Example: Step 3 is executed 4 seconds after the activation of step 2. This corresponds 
to a switch-on delay.
General transition condition
An alphanumerical identification code in 
brackets can be written on the left.
The transition condition is positioned on 
the right as a text or a Boolean expres­
sion.
Example:
Step 2 becomes active 
if start button S1 was 
pressed AND the piston 
of the lifting cylinder is 
in the retracted position 
(1B1).

(1) -- S1-1B1

instruction "1A1 ext. cyl" is exe­

8 is active for less than 4 sec., 
the instruction "1A1 ext. cyl." is 
executed for a shorter period.

Transition condition always TRUE
The symbol 1 in this context 
means that the transition 
condition is always satisified 
(TRUE). The result is a 
transient sequence. The 
triggering of the transition 
depends on the activation of 
the previous step.
Example:
Pressing start button 
S1 activates step 2 and 
switches valve solenoid 
1M1 on. If the start button 
is no longer activated, 
step 3 is launched and 
switches valve solenoid 
1M1 off. Cylinder 1A1 
retracts.

As long as the step is active, the value 1 (TRUE) is assigned to the variable. If it is no 
longer active, the value 0 (FALSE) is assigned.
Variants for the representation of actions (examples):
1A1 ext. cyl. => instruction
2A1 
=> designation of the drive
2V1-14 
=> designation of the valve connection
2M1 
=> solenoid in an electro-pneumatic control system
With assignment condition
Example: Press with step 2
If step 2 is active and the assignment 
condition B10 (bushing available) is satis­
fied, the value 1 (TRUE) is assigned to the 
variable 1M1 (solenoid). The solenoid 1M1 
switches over and the pneumatic piston 
1A1 extends.
A horizontal dash above the variable 
indicates the negation of a condition.
With time-driven assignment condition
Pneumatic circuit diagram 
with monostable component.
3 -B10
-B10
Boolean equation: 1M1=X2 B10
Example: Agitator with step 4
2 seconds after the activation of the filling level sensor 
B3 (rising edge: from 0 to 1), the agitator motor M1 is 
switched on. This corresponds to a switch-on delay.
After deactivation of B3 (falling edge: from 1 to 0), 
the agitator motor M1 continues running for another
5 seconds. This corresponds to a switch-off delay.

"solenoid 1M1" is executed less long.
This corresponds to a time limitation.

7.3 GRAFCET
385
Function charts for sequential controls (GRAFCET)
Example
Explanation
Action with storing effect
If a step becomes active, a value is permanently assigned to the variable of the action. The value remains assigned to 
this variable beyond the currently active function step until it is overwritten by another action.
Actions with storing effect can be set to the logical value "1" (TRUE) and reset in another step to the logical value "0" 
(FALSE) after a particular time has elapsed.
Stored with rising edge 
(activation of the step)
When step 2 is activated, the 
value 1 is assigned to the valve 
solenoid 1M1.
When step 6 is activated, the 
value 0 is assigned to the valve 
solenoid 1 M1.
The value is stored beyond the 
active period of the step until 
it is overwritten or deleted by 
another action.
When step 8 is activated, the 
current value of the variable 
increases incrementally by 1 
with each cycle.
Example: factory gate (state: OPEN)
Note: Storing with falling 
edge can only be realized 
with a PC or a PLC.
Stored with falling edge 
(deactivation of the step)
When step 3 is activated, nothing 
happens.
Only when step 3 is deactivated, 
the value 0 is assigned to the 
variable 1M1.
The assignment of this value to 
1M1 remains valid until the value 
is overwritten by another action.
If 1B2
- 1A1:=1
11 10S/X16
12
Motor M1:=1
Stored with event
The arrow pointing to the side indicates that the storing action is only executed when 
a particular event occurs.
When step 10 is active and the sensor 1B2 changes from 0 to 1 (rising edge t), the 
value 1 is assigned to the pneumatic cylinder 1A1. The value of the variable 1A1 is 
stored beyond the activity of function step 10 until it is overwritten.
With delay
When step 12 is active, the value 1 is assigned to 
the variable "motor" after 10 sec. have elapsed. 
The value of the variable M1 is stored beyond the 
activity of function step 12 until it is overwritten.

|~4A1] 
4B2
When step 16 is activated, the value 
1 is assigned to the compressed air 
supply connection 14.
The value is stored beyond the acti­
vity of step 16 until it is overwritten 
or deleted by another action.
The assignment of the value 1 causes 
the valve solenoid 2M1 to switch over. 
Even if the value turns to 0, the valve 
remains in this switching position. 
This type of storage is referred to as 
mechanical signal storage.
In order to avoid overlapping of 
signals, two inverse actions are 
executed for the same solenoid 
valve in each case.

7.3 GRAFCET
Function charts for sequential controls (GRAFCET) 6o848C(2oo2 w
Parallel branching (simultaneous sequence divergence)
Parallel branching allows a simultaneous activation of several partial sequences. If the first function step in the parallel 
branching becomes active, the partial sequences run independently of each other.
Example: Mixing of two liquids in an agitator
Two different liquids are to be mixed in an agitator vessel. Because of their different viscosities, first liquid 1 flows into 
the vessel via valve 1. When the liquid level attains filling mark Bl, the following happens simultaneously:
1. 
The motor M1 of the agitator is switched on and
2. 
valve V1 closes and liquid 2 flows into the tank via valve V2.
Both partial sequences are processed independently of each other.
When the liquid level reaches the filling mark B2, the agitator motor Ml and the valve V2 are switched off again.
GRAFCET
(storing effective actions)
-- S1 "Start S1
V1:=1
M1:=1
START S1
"Valve V1 is open
■■ B1 "Lower filling level attained
"Agitator M1 
switched on"
Technological scheme
__ liquid 2
V1:=0
Valve V1 closed
V2:=1
"Valve V2 open
liquid 1
— B2
■■ B2 "Upper filling level attained
■■ 1
M1:=0
"Agitator M1 
switched off"
V2:=0
"Valve V2 
closed"
Notes concerning the edges at valve V1:
The rising edge (positive edge) is the change 
from the state logic 0 to logic 1.
The falling edge (negative edge) is the change 
from the state logic 1 to logic 0.
rising edge
V1:=1
falling edge 
V1:=0

7.3 GRAFCET
387
Function charts for sequential controls (GRAFCET) 60848(2002-12)
Alternative branching (sequence selection divergence)
A sequence can branch into several alternative sequences. In an alternative branching, there must be a transition befo­
re and after each step. The transition condition must never be fulfilled together with any other transition condition. 
After the last active transition, the partial sequences are merged to a common sequence.
Example: Lifting equipment, actions for the selection of thin and thick workpieces
By activating the start button S1, the long-stroke lifting cylinder 1A1 (valve solenoid 1M1) extends and the sensor 1B2 
responds. There are two variations:
Variation 1: If a thick workpiece is available, sensor 2B4 responds. The pivoting cylinder 2A1 extends.
Variation 2: If a thin workpiece is available, sensor 2B3 responds. The pivoting cylinder remains in the retracted 
position.
The transfer cylinder 3A1 pushes the workpiece forward and retracts to its initial position. The long-stroke lifting 
cylinder 1A1 retracts.
GRAFCET
(actions with continuous effects)
Technological scheme

7.5 Hydraulics, Pneumatics
A

7.5 Hydraulics, Pneumatics
395
Basic terminology
Proportional valves
Example: Electrically actuated, pilot-operated 
4/3-spring centering valve
position control of the
actuator
Proportional valves are controlled via a continuously 
adjustable, electromagnetic actuator. They are mainly 
used in hydraulic engineering. The output signal, e.g. 
pressure, flow rate or flow direction, is a quantity propor­
tional to the input signal (current). The pressure, the flow 
rate and the flow direction allow the quick and precise 
adjustment of the piston force or velocity of a hydraulic 
cylinder, for instance, the speed or control of rotation of 
a hydraulic motor or the extension and retraction of a 
piston. These parameters can be adjusted automatically 
via a programmable logical controller (PLC) during opera­
tion of the equipment and matched to the automated 
process.
A proportional valve can also replace one or several 
valves, e.g. a directional control valve or a flow-control 
valve.
Circuit symbols (selection)
cf. DIN ISO 1219-1 (2007-12)
Proportional directional valve
Electro-hydraulic pilot- 
controlled proportional 
directional valve with 
position control of the main 
control and pilot stage, 
integrated electronics
Electro-hydraulic pilot- 
controlled directional 
valve, pilot stage acts 
continuously in both 
directions, integrated 
electronics
Electro-hydraulic pilot- 
controlled control valve, 
with position control of 
the main control and pilot 
stage, integrated 
electronics
Electro-hydraulic 
controlled directional valve 
with priority position in the 
event of power failure and 
electrical feedback, 
integrated electronics
Proportional directional 
valve, direct actuator
Electro-hydraulic linear 
drive, comprising a 
cylinder and a servo valve 
with step motor, mechani­
cal feedback of the cylinder 
position.
Proportional pressure valves
Proportional pressure-relief 
valves, direct actuator, sole­
noid acts on the valve cone 
via a spring
Proportional pressure­
relief valve, direct actuator, 
solenoid acts on valve 
cone, integrated electronics
Proportional pressure-re lief 
valve, direct actuator, with 
solenoid position control, 
integrated electronics

396
7.5 Hydraulics, Pneumatics
Circuit diagrams
cf. DIN ISO 1219-2 (1996-11)
Designing a circuit plan
The circuit is sub­
divided into subcircuits 
with related control 
functions.
The actual spatial 
arrangement of the 
components is not 
considered.
If the circuit diagram 
is made of several 
units, the unit number 
must be given, begin­
ning with numeral 1.
Components are 
arranged from bottom 
to top in the direction 
of power flow and 
from left to right.
Similar components 
or subassemblies are 
shown at the same 
height within a circuit.
Subassemblies such 
as throttle check 
valves or service units 
(FRL) are enclosed by 
a dash-dot line.
Devices actuated by 
drives, e. g. limit 
switches, are repre­
sented at their point of 
activation by a dash 
and their designator.
Hydraulic components 
are shown in their 
initial positions in the 
equipment before 
pressure is applied.
For roller plunger 
valves operating on 
one side only, a direc­
tional arrow is also 
placed at the dash.
Pneumatic compo­
nents are shown in 
their initial positions 
in the equipment 
before pressure is 
applied.
Components of a circuit
Drive elements
Motors, cylinders, valves
Actuators
Valves for controlling drive ele­
ments
Control elements
Valves for signal combination
Signal elements
Components used to trigger 
a switching action
Supply elements
Service unit (FRL), main valve
Example: Pneumatic circuit diagram with two cylinders (lifting device)
A

7.5 Hydraulics, Pneumatics
397
Pneumatic control
Sheet metals are manually fed to a bending tool. The tool should bend them to an angle of 90°. The clamping 
cylinder 1A1 retains the sheet in the working position while the bending cylinder 2A1 with the bending tool extends 
and forces the sheets to the desired angle. Subsequently, first the bending cylinder 2A1 and then the clamping 
cylinder 1A1 retract.

NC = normally closed 
NO = normally opened
Example for relay K5: Relay K5 has a normally open switch in section 10 and a normally open switch in section 11.
The switching element table is similar to the contact table (page 378) and is often used in practice. However it is 
not standardized. The table indicates the section in which a NC or NO relay contact can be found.
A

7.5 Hydraulics, Pneumatics
399
Electro-hydraulic control
A workpiece manufactured from two different materials is to be machined with a reamer. The activation of the start 
button S1 causes the piston to extend in feed mode and work on the softer material. Sensor 1B2 ensures that the 
feed motion is slowed down when working on the harder material. When the piston reaches 1B3, the machining of 
the hard material is finished and the piston retracts to its home position after a delay time of 2 sec.
Electro-hydraulic circuit diagram

7.6 Handling and robot systems

Coordinate systems and axes
cf. DIN ENISO 9787 
(2000-07)
Robot axes
Coordinate system
Robot main axes for positioning
Robot auxiliary axes 
for orientation

roll
To manipulate workpieces 
or tools in space, the fol­
lowing are necessary:
• 3 degrees of freedom for 
positioning and
• 3 degrees of freedom for 
orientation
To reach a desired point in space, 3 robot main axes are 
necessary.
3 robot auxiliary axes for 
spatial orientation
• R (roll)
• P (pitch)
• Y (yaw)
Cartesian robots
Articulated arm robots
3 translation axes 
(T axes) designated 
X, Y and Z
3 rotational axes 
(R-axes) designated 
A, B and C
Coordinate systems 
cf. din en iso 9787 (2000-07)
TZ1 
j|S|k
—1 >
Ro
. s2>'x
Base 
coordinate system
The base coordinate 
system references 
• the level mounting sur­
face for the X-Y plane
• the center of the robot for 
the Z axis
Flange 
coordinate system
The flange coordinate 
system references the end 
surface of the terminating 
main axis of the robot.
Tool 
coordinate system
The origin of the tool coor­
dinate system lies at the 
tool center point TCP (Tool 
Center Point).
The speed of the tool cen­
ter point is referred to as 
the robot speed and the 
path of tool travel as the 
robot trajectory.

7.7 CNC technology
407
Coordinate axes
cf. DIN 66217 (1975-121
Coordinate system
Right hand rule
Coordinate axes X, Y and Z are 
perpendicular to each other.
This arrangement can be repre­
sented by thumb, index finger 
and middle finger of the right 
hand.
Axes of rotation A, B and C are 
assigned to coordinate axes X, 
Yand Z.
When looking down one axis in 
the positive direction, the positive 
direction of rotation is clockwise.
Coordinate axes in programming
Example:
2-carriage lathe with programmable 
main spindle
Coordinate axes and the resulting 
directions of motion are aligned 
to the main slideways of the 
CNC machine and are essentially 
relative to the clamped workpiece 
with its workpiece zero point.
Positive directions of motion al­
ways result in greater coordinate 
values on the workpiece.
The Z axis always runs in the 
direction of the main spindle.
To simplify programming it is 
assumed that the workpiece 
remains motionless and only the 
tool moves.
Zero points and reference points
cf. DIN ISO 2806 (1996-041
Machine zero point M
Origin of the machine coordinate system and set by the machine 
manufacturer.
Workpiece zero point W
Origin of the workpiece coordinate system and set by the pro­
grammer based on processing aspects.
Tool holder reference point T
Lies central to the limiting face of the tool holder. On milling 
machines, this is the abutting surface of the tool spindle, on lathes 
the abutting face of the tool holder on revolver.
Reference point R
Origin of incremental position measurement system with a dis­
tance to the machine zero point set by the machine manufacturer.
Program zero point P0
Indicates the coordinates of the point at which the tool is located 
before start of the program. 
not standardized
A

408

7.7 CNC technology
413
Program structure of CNC machines according to PAL
PAL functions for lathes and milling machines
Programming coordinates and interpolation parameters
XA, YA, ZA
Absolute input of coordinate values relative to the workpiece zero point
XI, Yl, Zl
Incremental input of coordinate values relative to the current tool position
IA, JA, KA
Absolute input of the interpolation parameters relative to the workpiece zero point
T-addresses for tool change
T
Tool storage place in the tool revolver or holder
TC
Selection of the number from the offset memory
TR
Incremental tool radius or cutting edge offset in the selected offset memory
TL
Incremental tool length offset in the selected offset memory (milling)
TZ
Incremental tool length offset in Z direction in the selected offset memory (turning)
TX
Incremental diameter offset in X direction in the selected offset memory (turning)
Additional M-functions1> according to PAL
M13
Clockwise spindle rotation, coolant ON
M17
End of sub program
M14
Counter clockwise spindle rotation, coolant ON
M60
Constant feed
M15
Spindle and coolant OFF
M61
M60 + corner shaping

repetitions

be repeated

be repeated
Optional addresses:
H number of repetitions

G14 [H]
Optional addresses:
HO travel to tool change point simultaneously in all axes

PAL cycles for lathes
G84 I Drilling cycle
Structure of NC block
G84 ZI/ZA [D] [V] [VB] [DR] [DM] [R] [DA] [U] [O] [FR] [E]
Obligatory addresses:
Zl depth of hole, incremental depth relative to the current tool position
ZA depth of hole, absolute depth
Optional addresses (selection):
D pecking amount
(if D is not specified, pecking depth is
equal to the final drilling depth) 
Machining example
V safety distance
VB safety distance to the hole bottom
DR reduction value of the pecking amount
DM minimum infeed
R retract I eve l/di stance
DA spot-drilling depth
U dwell time at hole bottom
O dwell time selection
01 in seconds
02 in revolutions
FR rapid travel reduction in %
E spot-drilling feed

G31 Z/ZI/ZA X/XI/XA F D [ZS] [XS]
[DA] [DU] [Q] [O] [H]
Obligatory addresses:
Z, Zl, ZA thread end point in Z direction
Z controlled by G90/G91;
I incremental, A absolute
X, XI, Zl thread end point in X direction;
X controlled by G90/G91, 
I incremental, A absolute
F 
thread pitch
D 
thread depth
Optional addresses [..]:
ZS thread starting point, absolute in Z
XS thread starting point, absolute in X
DA approach
DU overrun
Q 
number of cuts
O 
number of idle cycles
H selection of infeed type and residual cuts (RC)
H1 without offset (radial infeed), RC OFF
H2 infeed at left flank, RC OFF
H3 infeed at right flank, RC OFF
H4 alternating infeed, RC OFF
H11 without offset (radial infeed), RC ON
H12 infeed at left flank, RC ON
H13 infeed at right flank, RC ON
H14 alternating infeed, RC ON

G81 Longitudinal rough-turning cycle
G82 I Rough facing cycle
Structure of NC block
G81 (or G82) H4 [AK] [AZ] [AX] [AE] 
[AS] [AV] [O] [Q] [V] [E]
or
G81 (or G82) D [H1/H2/H3/H24]
Obligatory addresses:
D infeed
Optional addresses [..]:
H type of machining
H1 rough machining, removal below 45° 
H2stepwise angle-cutting along the contour 
H3 like H1 with final contour cut
H4 contour finishing
H24 rough-machining with H2 and subsequent 
finishing
AK contour allowance parallel to the contour
AZ contour allowance in Z direction
AX contour allowance in X direction
AE immersion angle (final angle of the tool)
AS emergence angle (lateral adjustment angle of 
tool)
AV safety angle reduction for AE and AS
0 machining starting point
01: current tool position
02: calculated from contour
Q idle step optimization
01: optimization OFF
02: optimization ON
V safety distance for idle step optimization
G81: in Z direction
G82: in X direction
E immersion feed
Rough facing cycle with G82
Longitudinal rough turning 
cycle with G81

G88 Axial grooving cycle
G86 Z/ZI/ZA X/XI/XA ET [EB] [D] [..] (selection) 
G88 Z/ZI/ZA X/XI/XA ET [EB] [D] [..] (selection)
Obligatory addresses:
Z, Zl, ZA grooving position in Z direction;
Z controlled by G90/G91, 
Zl incremental, ZA absolute
X, XI, XA grooving position in X direction;
X controlled by G90/G91,
XI incremental, XA absolute
ET G86 absolute diameter of grooving depth
G88 absolute grooving depth
Optional addresses [..]:
EB grooving width and position
EB+ grooving in direction Z+ relative to the 
programmed grooving position P
EB- grooving in direction Z- relative to the 
programmed grooving position P
D pecking amount (if no value is specified, the 
pecking depth is equal to the groove depth ET)
AS flank angle of grooving at the starting point 
relative to the grooving direction (X or Z)
AE flank angle of grooving at the end point 
relative to the grooving direction (X or Z)
RO rounding or chamfering of upper corners 
RO+ rounding
Radial grooving cycle with G86
Axial grooving cycle with G88

RO- chamfer width
rounding or chamfering of lower corners
AK
AX

contour allowance parallel to the contour
contour allowance in X direction (contour offset)
EP setpoint definition for groove cutting (position P) 
EP1: setpoint in upper corner of the groove
EP2: setpoint in bottom corner of the groove 
type of processing
HI roughing cut H14 roughing and finishing
H2 plunge turning H24 plunge turning and finishing

H4 finishing

7.7 CNC technology
Program structure of CNC machines according to PAL
PAL cycles for milling machines
G1 | Linear interpolation with feed rate
Structure of NC block
G1 [X/XI/XA] [Y/YI/YA] [Z/ZI/ZA] [D] [AS].. (selection)
Obligatory addresses:
X, XI, XA X coordinate of the target point
Y, Yl, YA Y coordinate of the target point
Z, Zl, ZA Z coordinate of the target point
Optional addresses
D length of travel distance
AS ascent angle relative to the X axis
RN transition element to the next contour element
RN+ rounding radius RN- chamfer width 
H selection among two solutions via angle criterion
H1 small ascent angle H2 greater ascent angle
TC selection of the offset memory number
TR incremental change of the tool radius value
TL incremental change of the tool length offset
G11 Linear interpolation with polar coordinates
N10...
N15G1 X74Y16RN-12 
;P2
N20 G1 D65 AS120 RN+14 ;P3
Structure of NC block
G11 RP AP/AI [J/JA] [Z/ZI/ZA] [RN].. (Auswahl)
Obligatory addresses:
RP polar radius
AP polar angle relative to the positive X axis
Al incremental polar angle
Optional addresses [..]:
I, IA 
X coordinate of the polar center
J, JA 
Y coordinate of the polar center
Z, Zl, ZA infeed in Z direction
RN transition to the next contour element
RN+ rounding radius RN-chamfer width
TC selection of the offset memory number
TR incremental change of the tool radius value
TL incremental change of the tool length offset

;P2

selection of solution via arc length criterion
R+ shorter arc R- longer arc

RN transition element
RN+ rounding radius RN-chamfer width
0 selection of solution via arc length criterion
01 shorter arc 02 longer arc

G54-G57 Adjustable absolute zero point shift
Structure of NC block
G54 or G55 or G56 or G57
Explanatory notes:
The workpiece zero point W is determined by the 
commands G54 to G57 and has a defined distance to 
the machine zero point. The operator enters the shift 
values into the zero point register of the controller 
before starting the program. The zero point is always 
specified in absolute coordinates (XA, YA, ZA) rela­
tive to the machine zero point.

Structure of NC block

;P3

;P4
N10...
N15G54 ;W
N20
G59 [XA] [YA] [ZA] [AR]
Optional addresses [..]:
XA absolute X coordinate of the new workpiece zero point 
YA absolute Y coordinate of the new workpiece zero point 
ZA absolute Z coordinate of the new workpiece zero point 
AR angle of rotation of the new coordinate system relative 
to the X axis
Explanatory notes:
If the coordinate system of the workpiece is rotated in
machine 
zero point M

and in addition
